title-group.article-title: Modeling of an airborne torpedo attack and implementation on a simulation environment

contrib-group.aff: The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Information Technologies Institute, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Hakkı Murat Genç, The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Information Technologies Institute, 41470, Gebze, Kocaeli, Turkey. Email: murat.genc@bte.tubitak.gov.tr

fn.p: Fatih Aruk is a full-time researcher at the Centre of Research for Advanced Technologies of Informatics and Information Security, Kocaeli, Turkey. He is currently attending his PhD studies at Istanbul Technical University, Mechanical Engineering Department. His interest areas are computational solid mechanics, vibrations and dynamics.

Ahmet Faik Güven is a full-time researcher at Centre of Research for Advanced Technologies of Informatics and Information Security, Kocaeli, Turkey. He is currently attending his PhD studies at Istanbul Technical University, Control and Automation Engineering Department. His interest areas are non-linear systems and robotics.

Hakkı Murat Genç is a full-time chief researcher at Centre of Research for Advanced Technologies of Informatics and Information Security, Kocaeli, Turkey. He is currently attending his PhD studies at Istanbul Technical University, Control and Automation Engineering Department. His interest areas are intelligent control, numeric optimization and navigation algorithms.

Cesur Cevdet Okutan is a full-time senior researcher at Centre of Research for Advanced Technologies of Informatics and Information Security, Kocaeli, Turkey. He is currently attending his PhD studies at Istanbul Technical University, Control and Automation Engineering Department. His interest areas are underwater vehicles dynamics, dynamic system control and torpedo guidance algorithms.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Resuability, Interoperability and Composability in Air Warfare Simulations

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 The Society for Modeling and Simulation International
permissions.copyright-holder: The Society for Modeling and Simulation International

abstract.p: Airborne torpedoes are effective weapons that are used against surface and subsurface entities. A carrying platform, which may be a helicopter or plane, drops the weapon with or without a parachute. After a travelling period in the air, the torpedo hits the water and penetrates through it, forming a splash and a cavity. The initial conditions for the movement of the torpedo in the water are produced as a result of velocity at the water entrance and pitch angle and resistance force generated by the water itself. Under the water, the weapon transforms through its internal phases with the aim of a possible target hit. In this work, a certain part of the developed military training simulator is given in order to investigate an airborne torpedo attack scenario. For this purpose, aircraft and torpedo dynamic models, as well as guidance and control laws, are derived; torpedo fall and water entry analyses are also performed. Simulation results are given for each model and/or analysis separately. Modules and libraries for these model simulations are integrated into the component architecture of a commercial computer-generated forces toolkit simulation engine, namely VR-Forces. An original control architecture that is able to manage a wide variety of simulation components with different infrastructures has also been realized.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The requirement for building virtual military training simulations can be mostly traced to the fact that military field exercises are generally too costly to be used generously for staff training on military instruments. Such military simulations generally utilize a distributed simulation infrastructure, since they mostly require reduced execution time, geographical distribution, fault tolerance and integration of simulators that execute on different hardware platforms.1

In order to construct reliable and efficient training simulators, the dynamic behaviour of the simulation components should be modelled using high-fidelity analyses. Moreover, the integration environment needs to be modular to achieve co-operation between simulators built on different infrastructures in the simulation. In this work, a prototype scenario of an airborne torpedo attack is studied. The aircraft dynamics and control, torpedo fall and water entry analyses and underwater torpedo run have been investigated in detail. All these models are integrated on a single simulation framework that embodies multiple simulators using both a commercial infrastructure and a case-specific custom infrastructure.

In most of the commercial or military (training) simulators, (such as ORACOM from WASS S.p.A) falling and water entry of the airborne torpedo are neglected and the torpedo is assumed to start its motion inside the water. The simulator developed in this work has the main advantage and contribution of handling these subjects with the finite element method (FEM). Assuming a rigid body for the torpedo, thus neglecting any deformation analysis not needed in the simulation environment, the initial conditions for the angle of attack, velocity, pitch angle and depth can be found by utilizing the FEM.

The VR-Forces-based graphical user interface (GUI) provides the instructor – or the operator – with the necessary options for preparing scenarios, setting the required parameters of components acting in the scenario and assigning tasks to them. The architecture and development of the GUI is briefly given in the following sections. The prototype scenario utilized in this work concerns the engagement of an aircraft, loaded with airborne torpedoes, to a submarine target. The aircraft starts with the initial conditions imposed and travels through the waypoints assigned. It drops the torpedo at the expectation region specified by the operator. Initial conditions for the torpedo fall are inherited from the aircraft drop-time parameters. The torpedo falling phase is terminated by water entry. This highly non-linear water entry problem is analysed offline by the FEM for various speed and orientation values observed at the instant of water entrance. Then these results are interpolated according to the actual simulation conditions to initialize the underwater torpedo run. The torpedo goes through internal guidance phases and applies search patterns with the aim of acquiring target contact. After a possible contact with the target, the torpedo passes to the attack phase and is commanded by internal sonar logic. The torpedo run ends with a target hit or battery exhaustion.

The remaining parts of the paper are organized as follows. Section 2 gives a detailed explanation of the dynamic models employed in the simulation, including aircraft and the torpedo. In Section 3, torpedo falling and water entrance are studied to produce the initial conditions for the underwater torpedo run, which are the main contributions for this study. The finite element analysis given in this section is for the specific case presented in the paper. Section 4 is dedicated to the other important issues that compose a scenario run. Among these are the internal guidance schemes for the attack torpedo, submarine navigational intelligence and simulation architecture. Section 5 concludes the paper.

sec.title: 2.1.1 Dynamic Model
sec.p: Newton’s second law implies that the sum of the applied forces acting on the aircraft is equal to the time rate of change of the linear momentum; the summation of the applied moments acting on the aircraft is equal to the time rate of change of the angular momentum. These equations need to be solved in the body and stability axes that are fixed on the aircraft with the origins located at the centre of gravity of the aircraft. (The stability axis system is used to get the x-axis aligned with the oncoming flow direction. In other words, to obtain the stability axis, the body axis system is rotated around the y-body axis by the trim angle of attack and then re-fixed to the body of the aircraft.2) The results attained are transformed to the earth and inertial axes. In our simulation environment, since the aircraft is sub sonic, the earth and inertial axes are assumed to be the same axes defined in North–East–Down (NED) system. Body, stability and earth axes notations are given in Figure 1.

Aircraft motion dynamics can be investigated in four main parts: applied forces; applied moments; kinematics; and position expressions. All the constants and variables used in the aircraft modelling equations are defined in Table 1.

caption.p: Constant and variable definitions for aircraft modelling.

fn.p: δr : Rudder deflection angle ih : Horizontal tail incidence angle L : Lift
δa : Aileron deflection angle α : Angle of attack D : Drag
δe : Elevator deflection angle β : Sideslip angle T : Thrust

sec.p: Aircraft equations of motion can be written as given in the following equations:2,3
Applied forces:
Applied moments:
Kinematic equations:

Aircraft speed in the air is assumed to be same as aircraft real speed in the standard atmospheric condition, neglecting the wind effect. In this work, the non-linear aircraft dynamics are constructed using the stability derivatives derived by Roskam.4

sec.title: 2.1.2 Controller
sec.p: The six degrees of freedom (6-DOF) non-linear aircraft dynamic model has a high complexity. Motion control can be satisfied only if the coordination of all control surfaces is achieved. An aircraft has five main control structures: the aileron, elevator, rudder, horizontal tail stabilizer and thruster. Although the thruster is not an intrinsic control surface, aircraft altitude can be changed with the control of the thrust force.3 This thrust variation generates a pitch moment (termed a phugoid).

Although control surfaces affect each other (or, in other words, their responses are coupled over general system behaviour), aircraft motion can be separated basically as longitudinal and lateral motions. Lateral motion control is realized with the rudder and ailerons, whereas longitudinal motion control is achieved with elevators and thrusters.

Longitudinal control is performed with a discrete Proportional–Integral–Derivative (PID) controller, whereas a Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) controller is used for lateral motion control. The performance of the LQR controller highly depends on the certainty of system dynamic parameters and the observability of the system states. Aircraft dynamic models, except the engine model, have complete observability and reachability. Therefore, the LQR controller is utilized for lateral motion. On the other hand, due to compromised fidelity caused by the lack of an engine model, state-space formulation is omitted for longitudinal control and the PID controller is preferred after benchmark test results.

In observable and reachable multi input–multi output (MIMO) systems, the LQR controller yields satisfactory performance results. In our simulation environment, for lateral control, we assume all state variables are observable and their final states can be reached. Thus, the LQR controller provides not only stability, but also infinite gain margin and approximately sixty degrees of phase margin without increasing the system degree. System performance is easily tuned with adjusting the Q and R parameters of the LQR method. The LQR control methodology for a general case is summarized by Stevens and Lewis.5 To utilize the classical LQR methodology, the system needs to be linearized by using several equilibrium points. Effectiveness of the controller highly depends on equilibrium point density. In this work, a two-fold optimization is performed. Firstly, we determine the control vector by minimizing the quadratic penalty expression used in the LQR controller with arbitrary Q and R. Next, we determine Q and R in order to minimize performance index J through evolutionary computation. The performance index to be minimized for all controllers is selected as

where mp is the maximum overshoot, ts is the settling time, tr is the rise time and ess is the steady state error. Equation (5) formulizes a linear aggregation of different objectives. The coefficients of the expression represent the decision maker’s ranking of the relative importance of the four objective functions. Then a variant of the genetic algorithms (GAs) is applied to obtain the global minimum.

sec.title: 2.1.3 Longitudinal control
sec.p: Aircraft longitudinal control is realized with the elevator and thrusters. It is seen from Figure 1 that elevator deflection highly affects pitch angle θ, angular velocity Q and translational velocity W. Accordingly, elevator control input can be defined as
where (as the optimized parameters obtained by using the GA with the same performance index in (5))

Altitude change directly affects the relative Mach number.2 Thus, cruise speed has to be adjusted in connection with altitude change. Once the desired altitude is achieved, speed is regulated to the desired value. For the sake of simplicity, no engine model is employed and thrust expression for the standard propeller aircraft is used.2 That is, speed control is realized with a discrete PID controller having the trust ratio as the control signal. To discretize the controller, we need to approximate the integral and the derivative terms to forms so that they are suitable for computation by a computer (Equations (6) and (7)). The controller gains are acquired by optimizing (5):

sec.title: 2.1.4 Lateral control
sec.p: Aircraft lateral motion is controlled by co-operation of the rudder and ailerons. In the case where only a single control surface is used to navigate the aircraft, there may exist certain situations such that the obtained turn rate cannot satisfy optimum tracking for the desired route. On the other hand when using both control surfaces, highly accurate and robust coordination between them is needed.
At the trim position, it can be shown that the rudder control command can be written as

Rudder controller utilizing the LQR method is depicted in Figure 2. The heading of the aircraft is regulated to the desired heading angle determined by the guidance module. Once more, the coefficients for lateral controllers are achieved by minimizing (5) using the GA. Since the ailerons mainly affect roll dynamics, they also ensure stability. To achieve efficient turn rates, the ailerons control input can be defined as follows:
The block diagram of the LQR controller for roll compensation is given in Figure 3.

sec.title: 2.2.1 Kinematics and dynamics of a torpedo
sec.p: When modelling the physical behaviour of a torpedo, it is necessary to define two coordinate systems: an earth-fixed coordinate system, which is fixed to earth, and a body-fixed system, which is fixed to the torpedo body (it moves with the torpedo). See Figure 4 for a diagram of the torpedo coordinate system.6
The 6-DOF torpedo equations of motion are expressed in the following equations according to the theory of rigid body dynamics:

F and M are force and moments acting on an underwater vehicle and they mainly consist of four parts: (a) hydrodynamics/hydrostatics force and moments; (b) external (environmental) loads; (c) control surface forces (rudder, fin, etc.); and (d) propulsion (propeller) forces. In this study standard (Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers – SNAME) notation is used and is summarized in Table 2.7

The drag force and moment terms are calculated by using Missile DATCOM software as a function of angle of attack, angle of sideslip, rudder angle, aileron angle, elevator angle and diameter of torpedo. In addition, the added mass force and moment coefficients are calculated by using empirical formulas given by Timothy.8 The details of calculation of these terms are not in the scope of this work. The environmental effects, such as wind and waves, are neglected as they have minor impact for underwater vehicles. Ocean currents are also neglected for model simplicity, but can be easily implemented by using a linear aggregation function with the final velocity term

where

relative to the moving vessel is conveniently expressed in terms of two angles: angle of attack and angle of sideslip.6
The dynamic equations of motion can be written in a matrix form by grouping terms appropriately. The left-hand side contains mass-related, inertia-related and acceleration terms:
That rearrangement leaves lift, drag, buoyancy, weight, propulsion thrust and other forces and moments on the right-hand side of the equation:
Constant and variables used in (15) and (16) are given in Table 3.

caption.p: Constant and variable definitions for underwater vehicle modelling.

tr.td: Ix, Iy, Iz: moment of inertia

td.italic: hydrodynamic coefficients: calculated by using missile Datcom
added mass coefficients calculated by empirical formulas

sec.p: While generating the dynamic model of a submarine (or any underwater vehicle), it is appropriate to follow the same procedure that we indicated for the torpedo model. Since we use the same notation, 6-DOF equations of motion (11) and (12) are applied for the submarine by considering the parameters such as mass, inertia, centre of mass and centre of buoyancy. In addition to this, force and moments acting on the submarine are computed by considering the vehicle’s geometry by using the same empirical formulas given by Timothy.8

sec.title: 2.2.2 Controller design
sec.p: The torpedo shape is symmetric in the x–z and x–y planes, so it is appropriate to decouple its motion in the steering and the depth planes.9
As the motion of the torpedo is analysed separately in both planes, the terms regarding the depth plane can be neglected in deriving the equation of motion for the steering plane:9
According to the equations of motion (11) and (12), we have the following expressions in the state-space representation form:
The similar argument holds and the steering plane parameters can be taken as zero when deriving equations of motion for the depth plane:
The equations of motion given in (11) and (12) can now be rewritten as in Equation (20):

sec.title: 3. The Fall and the water entry of the torpedo
sec.p: The plane drops an airborne torpedo with the initial conditions that are determined by the dropping instant dynamic parameters. The velocity, the angle of attack and the angle with the sea surface of the torpedo as it hits the sea surface were evaluated according to these initial conditions. A two-dimensional (2D) MATLAB Simulink model was built for this purpose. Then the results obtained from this free falling analysis were used as input to the water entry analysis. In this work, this highly non-linear problem was solved using the FEM for a certain case. Finally, the initial conditions for the underwater dynamic model of the torpedo have been obtained.

sec.title: 3.1 Modeling the fall of the torpedo
3.1.1 Axial and normal force calculation
sec.p: As the torpedo is launched from the plane, it falls freely under the effect of gravity and aerodynamics, such as drag and lift forces. For the analysis of the motion of the airborne torpedo during the fall, it was assumed that the torpedo can be modelled as a cylindrical object. Then the variation of drag and lift coefficients with the change of angle of attack can be calculated as presented by Hoerner:13
The normal and axial forces can be calculated using these expressions. The resulting equations are:14
Thus the normal and axial forces are described as
In Equations (31) and (32), A is the cross-sectional area of the cylinder given as the product of the length and the diameter of the cylinder.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Pitch moment calculation
sec.p: According to Soong,15 the pitching moment is assumed to be the moment of these drag and lift forces given by Equations (29) and (30) acting at the centre of the pressure, which remains at a fixed distance d from the centre of gravity. Here, the volume centre was taken to be the centre of pressure. Since the torpedo is assumed to be axis symmetric, axial force applied to the centre of volume will not create any pitching moment about the centre of gravity. So, the pitching moment equation is given by
Here, d is the distance from the volume centre to the centre of gravity.

sec.title: 3.1.3 Simulation
sec.p: By using the three degrees of freedom (3-DOF) block of the Aerospace Blockset, a Simulink model was built for calculating the motion of the torpedo during free fall under the effects of gravity, as well as the aerodynamic moment and forces given by Equations (31)–(33).

In the simulation example, the initial conditions for a certain scenario are to be used in the analysis. In this scenario, at the moment when the torpedo is left for free fall, the airplane is assumed to be flying with a speed of 100 Knots at 350 feet of altitude with a zero pitch angle. With these values applied to the simulation as initial conditions, the results in Figure 6 were obtained for the free fall of the torpedo.

caption.p: The two-dimensional motion, pitch angle and velocity of the torpedo during free fall.

sec.p: Inspecting Figure 6, for the given initial conditions, the torpedo will hit the water with a pitch angle of −18.6 degrees and vertical and horizontal velocity components of, respectively, 49.5 and 43.4 m/s. These values constitute the initial conditions for the water entry analysis.

sec.title: 3.2 Water entry analysis
sec.p: The vertical entry of a body into a liquid can be divided into several phases: the impact of the body on the liquid at the moment of the initial contact; the beginning of the penetration with the formation of a splash; cavity formation; the closing of the cavity; and jet formation.16 The presence of the acceleration leads to the so-called virtual mass effect, resulting in a resisting force associated with the acceleration of the body. The virtual mass is affected by the geometry of the hitting part, as well as the shape of the free surface and the history of the motion. The solution of the problem is thus greatly dependent upon the change in the boundary shape of the water surface, which is highly non-linear, making the problem extremely complex and difficult to solve analytically.17
The equation of the motion of the body during water entry, starting from contact with the surface of the liquid, can be represented as16

Here, M is the mass of the body, v is its velocity, t is time,
c
x
is the drag coefficient,
ρ
is the density of the water, A is the area of the midsection of the body and m is the virtual mass. The motion of the body was assumed to be one dimensional. Even in this simple representation, the coefficients
c
x
and m are variable and will generally be a function of hitting velocity, the geometry of the hitting part and the shape of the free surface. Moreover, as the torpedo hits the sea surface with an angle of attack and/or pitch angle, a pitching moment will result in a rotational movement in addition to the translational travel of the torpedo into the sea. In conclusion, analytical treatment of the subject is impractical.

Most recently, finite element analysis has been widely used in transient dynamics analysis,17 especially for high-speed torpedo water entry impact.18 In these works, the concern is generally the crashworthiness and durability of the torpedo as it hits the sea surface. In this work, however, the aim is to use the FEM as a tool to find the initial angle of attack, velocity, pitch angle and depth (or simply the initial conditions) for the following underwater simulations of the torpedo. Although the FE simulations are still too long to be placed in a real-time simulation, some empirical formulations can be constructed for the required initial conditions of the following underwater simulations. This can be achieved by repeating FE simulations with varying initial conditions. However, only one case was presented in here.

sec.title: 3.2.1 The finite element model
sec.p: The Eulerian element capability of some advanced FE packages, such as LS Dyna, Abaqus or MSC Dytran can be used for the modelling of liquid. In this formulation, the material flows through the fixed mesh in space, making it suitable for large deformation analysis. Since the aim is to determine the initial conditions for the following dynamic simulations, rather than the durability of the torpedo, the body was assumed to be rigid so that the stable time increment for the explicit integration procedure was relatively large compared with the situation of a deformable torpedo. This is advantageous, since the aim of the simulation requires relatively longer simulation times than a crashworthiness analysis would necessitate.
The torpedo geometry is simplified and rigid Lagrangian shell elements were used for discretization. Cubic brick Eulerian elements were used for the water medium.

The Eulerian water region and the undeformable Lagrangian mesh of the torpedo are shown in Figure 7. The entire Eulerian mesh region is not initially filled with water, as there is an empty region over the water-filled zone. This initially empty mesh is created in the region where the water will likely splash and fill during the simulation. The effect of air in this region is neglected.

caption.p: The sectional view of the finite element model of the water entry problem.

sec.p: Since the water region extends sufficiently large in reality, non-reflecting boundary conditions are applied to the outer boundaries of the Eulerian region. The hydrostatic pressure due to gravity is also considered. The contact interaction between the Eulerian and Lagrangian meshes is activated. The torpedo is initially positioned according to the results of the previous free fall analysis, as shown in Figure 7. The vertical and horizontal velocity results of the same analysis are applied to the centre of mass of the torpedo as initial conditions. The run time for the simulations is 0.2 seconds.

sec.title: 4. Results
sec.p: The deformation of the water and the dive of the torpedo into the sea are shown in Figure 8. The analysis should be run for a longer time period to see the closing of the cavity.

caption.p: The penetration of the torpedo into the sea and the formation of the cavity (the top pictures are overviews while the bottom ones are a sectional presentation of the entry).

sec.p: The velocity and displacement variation in the vertical and horizontal directions, as well as the pitch rate and pitch angle results are depicted in Figure 9. A rapid decrease in vertical and horizontal velocities is observed. The inclined impact of the torpedo to the sea results in a sudden pitch rate, the value of which is damped in later stages of the simulation.

caption.p: The finite element simulation results of the torpedo motion.

sec.p: At the end of the simulation, the results obtained for the horizontal displacement, the depth and the pitch angle of torpedo respectively are 6.48 m, −2.97 m and −1.25°. The final results for the vertical and horizontal velocities and pitch rate are 20.54 m/s, −4.88 m/s and 5.37 deg/s.

sec.title: 4.1 Scenario run
sec.p: In this section complementary issues for a basic torpedo attack scenario will be given. In the first section torpedo (internal) guidance is briefly summarized as the way it is implemented in the simulation environment. The second section is a short introduction of the fundamental evasive countermeasures performed by the submarine. Modules and libraries for the model simulations are integrated into the component architecture of a commercial computer-generated forces (CGF) toolkit simulation engine. In addition, an original control architecture that is able to manage all kinds of simulation components with different infrastructures has been realized. This integrated simulation architecture is described in the final section.

sec.title: 4.2 Underwater torpedo run and guidance
sec.p: As an airborne torpedo dives into the water, the battery is activated and the torpedo takes its preset course and depth with the use of the propulsion system and control surfaces. Following the stabilization and taking the preset course and depth, the phases that the torpedo undergoes during its operation can be generally classified as search, target acquisition and homing.19,20

sec.title: 4.2.1 Search phase
sec.p: In the search phase, the torpedo seeks to acquire target contact. This search is steered by the internal guidance logic of the torpedo and an attempt to gain acquisition is made by means of acoustic sonar. The sonar module is triggered by target noise in a passive manner or the torpedo actively transmits pulses of acoustic energy and receives echoes from the target. In this stage, the torpedo should move in a manner such that the volume swept by its acoustic sonar is greatly increased. This necessity obliges the torpedo to leave its straight course. There are basic search patterns imposed on the torpedo guidance model to provide this behaviour, such as the snake search pattern and circle search pattern.

In the snake search, the torpedo seeks a region along its preset course by changing its heading periodically until acquiring a contact from the target. This movement is performed with an applicable angle deviation (generally chosen as 30°–60°) for both sides of the preset course. In the circle search, the torpedo moves around a fictitious circle with a certain angular velocity. This movement leads the torpedo to have a uniform search region around its search start point.
Beside these main search methods, the simulation control module ensures generation of further search patterns by combination or modification of these two methods.

sec.title: 4.2.2 Target acquisition phase
sec.p: The target acquisition phase starts with target contact acquisition. This phase is a transition phase in which the torpedo tries to confirm information about the target by checking certain sonar criteria. The sonar outputs are functions of number, position and orientation of the sonar beams. On the other hand, in the acquisition and homing phases, the guidance commands are generated depending on the measurements obtained in each sonar beam. The details of internal sonar guidance are not in the scope of this work, and thus will not be detailed.

sec.title: 4.2.3 Homing phase
sec.p: In the homing phase, the torpedo is guided in a manner such that the relative bearing of the target observed by the torpedo is forced to be minimized. That is to say, it is attempted to align the heading of the torpedo along the line of sight between the torpedo and target. If target contact loss occurs in the homing phase, the torpedo returns to the search phase and performs search patterns in a similar manner to acquire contact from the target.

Figures 10 and 11 illustrate two possible torpedo trajectories while homing in on the target with different search patterns. The torpedo was assumed to dive into the water at reference point ([0, 0]). The torpedo moves along a straight path in order to stabilize and take preset depth until the search phase starts. Before the target contact, the torpedo follows the preset search pattern (a snake search in Figure 10 and a circle search in Figure 11). After the contact conditions were satisfied (i.e. in passive homing, exceeding a minimum signal-to-noise ratio), the torpedo moves toward the target until a hit is achieved.

caption.p: The torpedo trajectory with the snake search method.
The torpedo trajectory with the circle search method.

sec.p: The whole trajectory of the integrated system for a certain case is shown in Figure 12.

caption.p: Trajectory of actors in the integrated system.

sec.title: 4.3 Submarine navigational intelligence
sec.p: The submarine model used in the simulation utilizes navigational intelligence, or – to some extent – the captain model. There are three main actions that can be chosen with respect to an encountered situation:

list-item.p: employing a decoy, jammer or torpedo;

sec.p: Generally, a combination of these actions is used. For example, one of the mostly applied methods is to employ a decoy that imitates the acoustic signature of the submarine, and receding in the opposite direction (Figure 13).21

caption.p: A combination of decoy employing and receding.

sec.p: Evading manoeuvres work as proactive cautions and need prior information, generally. The navigational intelligence model of the simulator provides a solution for the evading of any moving/unmoving target with a certain safety radius. For example, before torpedo launching, these manoeuvres can be used to escape from the sonar/weapon range of the target. The danger zone is characterized by a centre (torpedo or enemy position) and a radius (correlated with the danger level).
An illustration of classical evading maneuver is given in Figure 14.

sec.title: 4.4 Simulation architecture
sec.p: Since simulation components are built on different infrastructures on the simulation network, maintaining coordination becomes a challenging problem. There are several commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) frameworks that facilitate development of CGF, scenario management and run control for distributed simulations. However, they may not always meet the requirements of virtual military training simulation systems. In this work, we utilized dynamic platform models with several sensors, weapons and artificial intelligence within a high-fidelity virtual military training simulation. Modules and libraries for high-fidelity entity simulation are integrated into the component architecture of a commercial CGF toolkit simulation engine for executing battlefield scenarios, namely VR-Forces. Figure 15 gives a GUI snapshot from the scenario management console. Details for the simulation architecture can be found in MAK Techno-logies22,23 Haklidir et al.24

sec.title: 4.4.1 Integration of high-fidelity motion models into the simulation system
sec.p: An entity that is simulated in a training-critical simulation requires various models, each of which realizes a specific entity behaviour, such as a sensor or a weapon system of the entity, the entity’s motion model, its motion controller or a more specialized model, such as the land avoidance algorithm. Each of these models has been implemented as a distinct software library in order to maintain modularity and reusability. Then, each library is embedded into the CGF simulation engine.

Figure 16 displays the integration of a high-fidelity model library (motion model library for surface entities in this case) into the component architecture of VR-Forces CGF application. The data flow between the components is displayed as arrows. All the components in Figure 16, except for the model library, have been derived from original VR-Forces components to adapt the model library.

caption.p: Integration of surface entity specific motion model library into the VR-Forces component architecture.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, a part of the integrated simulation framework developed for military training purposes have been given. The modelling and control of the basic components of the simulation, as well as the integration environment, has been derived and presented on a particular case.

The comprehensive simulation environment provides defining surface, subsurface and air platforms. The platforms can be assigned numerous tasks, such as moving on a predefined trajectory, launching a weapon, snorting, avoiding, etc. However, in this work, only a prototype attack scenario with minimum actors has been derived and investigated.

The platforms, including torpedo, dynamic and control models, are developed from scratch and reported by omitting some common intermediate steps. Combining rigid body dynamic models with a finite element continuum model, a multi-disciplinary modelling approach was achieved and successfully integrated.

ack.p: The authors of the paper would like to thank Dr Sevgi Akgün for supervising the overall study as the project manager.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
